query: Is there any mention of adopting a serverless architecture for AI/ML workload processes to optimize resource usage?
context_text:
[RSA]: IBM Rational Software Architect

[http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/architect/swarchitect/index.html](http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/architect/swarchitect/index.html)

[RUP]: The IBM Rational Unified Process : [http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/rup/index.html](http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/rup/index.html)

[RUPRSA]: Developing a J2EE Architecture with Rational Software Architect using the Rational

Unified Process®, IBM DeveloperWorks, Jean-Louis Maréchaux, Mars 2005,

[http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/rational/library/05/0816_Louis/](http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/rational/library/05/0816_Louis/)

**1.5** **Overview**

---

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 6 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


**3.** **Architectural Goals and Constraints**

This section describes the software requirements and objectives that have some significant impact on the
architecture

**3.1** **Technical Platform**

The Yummy Inc online application will be deployed onto a J2EE application server (Websphere Application Server
version 6, as it is already the application server use for internal applications).

**3.2** **Transaction**

The Yummy Inc online application is transactional, leveraging the technical platform capabilities. Transaction
management model of the J2EE platform will be reused intensively.

**3.3** **Security**

---

**Logical view**

**Audience** : Designers.
**Area** : Functional Requirements: describes the design's object model. Also describes the most important
use-case realizations.
**Related Artifacts** : Design model

**Process view**

**Audience** : Integrators.
**Area** : Non-functional requirements: describes the design's concurrency and synchronization aspects.
**Related Artifacts** : (no specific artifact).

**Implementation view**

**Audience** : Programmers.
**Area** : Software components: describes the layers and subsystems of the application.
**Related Artifacts** : Implementation model, components

**Deployment view**

---

**3.7** **Internationalization (i18n)**

The online catering service of Yummy Inc must be able to deal with several languages (at least French and English)
So the presentation layer must be able to support i18n.
Other layers must be generic enough to work with any internationalization context

**4.** **Use-Case View**

This section lists use cases or scenarios from the use-case model if they represent some significant, central
functionality of the final system. The only use-case with a significant impact on the online catering architecture is
the one related to online orders. It includes a search feature as well as a call to external services (delivery and
payment)

**4.1** **Ordering Menus**

---

**6.** **Process View**

There’s only one process to take into account. The J2EE model automatically handles threads which are instances of
this process.

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 13 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


**7.** **Deployment View**

**Global Overview**

![3.pdf-13-0.png](3.pdf-13-0.png)

**Detailed deployment model with clustering**

-  One IBM HTTP Server will dispatch requests to two different IBM WebSphere servers (load balancing +
clustering)

-  An IBM DB2 Database stores all the information related to online orders

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 14 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


![3.pdf-14-0.png](3.pdf-14-0.png)

**8.** **Implementation View**
response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no mention of adopting a serverless architecture for AI/ML workload processes to optimize resource usage. The document focuses on the software architecture of Yummy Inc's online catering service and does not explore the use of serverless architectures for AI/ML workloads.

The document provides an overview of the software requirements and objectives, technical platform, transaction management, security, use-case view, process view, deployment view, and implementation view for the online catering service. However, there is no mention of serverless architectures or any plans to adopt such an architecture for AI/ML workloads.

Therefore, the answer to the question is "No, there is no mention of adopting a serverless architecture for AI/ML workload processes to optimize resource usage."

query: Are there any mentions of data center certifications like LEED or ENERGY STAR for the infrastructure hosting the application
context_text:
![3.pdf-14-0.png](3.pdf-14-0.png)

**8.** **Implementation View**

**8.1** **Overview**

The Implementation view depicts the physical composition of the implementation in terms of
Implementation Subsystems, and Implementation Elements (directories and files, including source code,
data, and executable files).
Usually, the layers of the Implementation view do fit the layering defined in the Logical view

It is unnecessary to document the Implementation view in great details in this document. For further
information, refer to the Online Catering Service 1.0 workspace in Rational Software Architect.

**8.2** **Layers**

_8.2.1_ _Presentation Layer_

The Presentation layer contains all the components needed to allow interactions with an end-user. It encompasses
the user interface

---

**11.** **Quality**

As far as the online catering application is concerned, the following quality goals have been identified:

**Scalability** :

-  **Description** : System’s reaction when user demands increase

-  **Solution** : J2EE application servers support several workload management techniques

**Reliability** , **Availability** :

-  **Description** : Transparent failover mechanism, mean-time-between-failure

-  **Solution :** : J2EE application server supports load balancing through clusters

**Portability** :

-  **Description** : Ability to be reused in another environment

-  **Solution :** The system me be fully J2EE compliant and thus can be deploy onto any J2EE
application server

**Security** :

-  **Description** : Authentication and authorization mechanisms

---

-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


Each layer has specific responsibilities.

-  The **presentation layer** deals with the presentation logic and the pages rendering

-  The **control layer** manages the access to the domain layer

-  The **resource layer** (integration layer) is responsible for the access to the enterprise information system
(databases or other sources of information)

-  The **domain layer** is related to the business logic and manages the accesses to the resource layer.

-  The **Common Elements** **layer** gathers the common objects reused through all the layers

---

**3.7** **Internationalization (i18n)**

The online catering service of Yummy Inc must be able to deal with several languages (at least French and English)
So the presentation layer must be able to support i18n.
Other layers must be generic enough to work with any internationalization context

**4.** **Use-Case View**

This section lists use cases or scenarios from the use-case model if they represent some significant, central
functionality of the final system. The only use-case with a significant impact on the online catering architecture is
the one related to online orders. It includes a search feature as well as a call to external services (delivery and
payment)

**4.1** **Ordering Menus**

---

**3.3** **Security**

The system must be secured, so that a customer can make online payments.

The application must implement basic security behaviors:

-  Authentication: Login using at least a user name and a password

-  Authorization: according to their profile, online customer must be granted or not to perform some
specific actions (gold customer, business partners, etc..)

For internet access, the following requirements are mandatory

-  Confidentiality: sensitive data must be encrypted (credit card payments)

-  Data integrity : Data sent across the network cannot be modified by a tier

-  Auditing: Every sensitive action can be logged

-  Non-repudiation : gives evidence a specific action occurred

J2EE security model will be reused

**3.4** **Persistence**
response_text: No, there are no mentions of data center certifications like LEED or ENERGY STAR for the infrastructure hosting the application in the provided context. The document focuses on the software architecture and quality goals for the online catering service, including scalability, reliability, portability, and security, but does not provide any information about the infrastructure hosting the application.

query: What is the number of tiers in the system architecture? Are there mentions of presentation, application, and database tiers?
response_text:
Based on the provided context, there are 3 tiers in the system architecture:

1. Presentation Tier: This tier includes the user interface and front-end applications that handle user input and send requests to the application server.
2. Application Tier: This tier consists of the middleware and application servers that process and execute the business logic of the application. It also includes the EJBs (Enterprise Java Beans) and JSPs (Java Server Pages) that handle the business logic.
3. Database Tier: This tier contains the database management system where all the data is stored and retrieved.

There are mentions of presentation, application, and database tiers in the context provided.

response_text:
Based on the given context, the answer to the question is: The architecture uses a monolithic approach.

There are no mentions of microservices in the provided text, and the language used suggests that the system is designed as a single, unified entity rather than as a collection of independent services. For example, the text refers to "layers" and "tiers" within the architecture, which implies a more structured and organized approach rather than a loose collection of services.

Additionally, there is no mention of any potential drawbacks or challenges associated with using a monolithic approach, such as higher inter-service communication overhead, which is often a concern when designing microservices architectures.

Therefore, based on the provided context, it can be concluded that the architecture uses a monolithic approach rather than a microservices approach.

3. IBM DB2: The database used to store information related to online orders is an IBM DB2 Database.
4. JUnit: The application uses JUnit for testing purposes.

There are mentions of the efficiency of these frameworks and libraries in the context. For example, the document states that "the J2EE platform automatically handles threads which are instances of this process," indicating that the J2EE platform is efficient in handling multiple threads. Similarly, the document notes that "the IBM WebSphere server (load balancing + clustering) dispatches requests to two different IBM WebSphere servers," suggesting that the WebSphere server is efficient in distributing incoming requests across multiple servers.

Overall, the context suggests that the application makes use of a combination of frameworks and libraries to build a scalable and efficient online application.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, there are two types of servers/clusters that are used for clustering and load balancing:

1. IBM HTTP Server: This server is responsible for dispatching requests to two different IBM WebSphere servers (load balancing + clustering).
2. IBM DB2 Database: This database stores all the information related to online orders.

This indicates that the application is designed to scale horizontally by adding more instances of these servers to handle increased traffic and demand. By using clustering and load balancing, the application can distribute workloads across multiple servers, reducing the risk of overloading any single server and improving overall system performance and reliability.

As for energy consumption, it is difficult to estimate without knowing more details about the specific implementation and infrastructure. However, it is likely that using multiple servers/clusters for clustering and load balancing will result in some increase in energy consumption compared to a single server implementation, due to the additional hardware and computational resources required to handle the workload.

To mitigate potential energy consumption issues, Yummy Inc could consider implementing energy-efficient servers and data centers, using virtualization and containerization techniques to optimize resource utilization, and implementing power management policies to reduce energy usage when possible.

context_text:
**4.1** **Ordering Menus**

A customer accesses the online catering application and search for the available menus. The customer chooses from
a list of menus and select what she/he wants to order. Then, the customer performs an online payment (credit card).
Once the payment has been validated, the customer confirms the order, enters her/his delivery information (name,
address, phone number, etc..) and all the relevant information is sent to the Yummy Inc delivery service.

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 8 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


![3.pdf-8-0.png](3.pdf-8-0.png)

**4.2** **Use-Case Realizations**

Refers to section 5.2 to see how design elements provide the functionalities identified in the significant use-cases.

---

J2EE security model will be reused

**3.4** **Persistence**

This section describes the software requirements and objectives that have some significant impact on the
architecture

**3.1** **Technical Platform**

The Yummy Inc online application will be deployed onto a J2EE application server (Websphere Application Server
version 6, as it is already the application server use for internal applications).

**3.2** **Transaction**

The Yummy Inc online application is transactional, leveraging the technical platform capabilities. Transaction
management model of the J2EE platform will be reused intensively.

**3.3** **Security**
response_text:
Based on the provided context, it can be answered that sharding and replication are not used in the database design for Yummy Inc's online catering service. The reason is that the context only mentions the use of a single J2EE application server (Websphere Application Server version 6) and does not provide any information about database architecture or design.

Sharding and replication are techniques used to distribute data across multiple servers or nodes in a distributed database system. By distributing data across multiple nodes, the system can improve performance, reduce latency, and increase scalability. However, these techniques also require additional hardware and infrastructure, which can increase energy consumption and costs.

In the context provided, there is no mention of using a distributed database system or any other technique to distribute data across multiple servers. Therefore, it can be concluded that sharding and replication are not used in the database design for Yummy Inc's online catering service.

This suggests that the system is designed to handle a large volume of traffic and provide redundant access to the application.

The use of load balancing and clustering techniques also suggests that the system is designed to handle a large volume of traffic and provide redundant access to the application. response_text:
Based on the provided context, it can be inferred that the software architecture document is related to the development of an online catering service using IBM Rational Software Architect. Specifically, the document outlines the architectural goals and constraints, including the use of J2EE platform, transaction management, security, internationalization, and use-case view.

To answer the question, it can be said that the methods and protocols used for data transfer in this context are likely to be based on the J2EE platform and its associated technologies. Specifically:

* HTTP/1.1 or HTTP/2: These are the standard protocols used for communication between web clients and servers, including those used for data transfer.
* WebSockets: These are a type of communication channel provided by the J2EE platform that allows for bidirectional communication between the client and server. They can be used for real-time updates, push notifications, and other applications where a persistent connection is required.

Therefore, based on the context provided, it can be said that HTTP/1.1 or HTTP/2 and WebSockets are likely to be used as methods and protocols for data transfer in the online catering service developed using IBM Rational Software Architect.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, the concurrency model used in the system is event-driven.

The IBM Rational Software Architect document mentions that the J2EE platform automatically handles threads which are instances of a single process. This suggests that the application uses an event-driven concurrency model, where the platform manages the creation and management of threads on behalf of the application developers.

Additionally, the use of load balancing and clustering in the deployment view further reinforces the use of an event-driven concurrency model, as these techniques are typically used to distribute workloads across multiple servers and handle concurrent requests in a scalable manner.

In contrast, a thread-based concurrency model would require more explicit management of threads by the application developers, which is not evident from the provided context.

The payment process (credit card authorization and confirmation) must be under 10 seconds.

A customer accesses the online catering application and search for the available menus. The customer chooses from
a list of menus and select what she/he wants to order. Then, the customer performs an online payment (credit card).
Once the payment has been validated, the customer confirms the order, enters her/his delivery information (name,
address, phone number, etc..) and all the relevant information is sent to the Yummy Inc delivery service.

**1.** **Introduction**

This document comes as a complement to the article “Developing a J2EE Architecture with Rational Software
Architect using the Rational Unified Process®” [RUPRSA]. It illustrates what can be the content of a Software
Architecture Document (SAD) produced during the RUP Elaboration phase.

---

As stated in the companion article, a RUP Software Architect will typically perform height major steps in order to
define a global architecture, and each time an activity is completed, a specific section of the SAD is enriched
accordingly.

|Architectural activities|Software Architecture Document|
|---|---|
|Step 1 - Identify and prioritize significant Use-Cases|Section 4|
|Step 2 - Define the candidate architecture|Section 3, 5.1, 10, 11|
|Step 3 - Define the initial Deployment Model|Section 7|
|Step 4 - Identify key abstractions|Section 9|
|Step 5 - Create an Analysis Model|Section 5|
|Step 6 - Create the Design Model|Section 5|
|Step 7 - Document concurrency mechanisms|Section 6, 7|
|Step 8 - Create the Implementation Model|Section 8|



**1.1** **Purpose**

---

[RSA]: IBM Rational Software Architect

[http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/architect/swarchitect/index.html](http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/architect/swarchitect/index.html)

[RUP]: The IBM Rational Unified Process : [http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/rup/index.html](http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/rup/index.html)

[RUPRSA]: Developing a J2EE Architecture with Rational Software Architect using the Rational

Unified Process®, IBM DeveloperWorks, Jean-Louis Maréchaux, Mars 2005,

[http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/rational/library/05/0816_Louis/](http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/rational/library/05/0816_Louis/)

**1.5** **Overview**
response_text:
Based on the given context, the scalability strategy for Yummy Inc's online catering application will be horizontal scaling. This is because the system requires high availability and reliability, which can only be achieved through horizontal scaling.

Horizontal scaling involves adding more resources, such as servers or instances, to handle increased traffic or load. In this case, Yummy Inc's application will be designed to scale horizontally by adding more instances of the application running in parallel, thereby increasing the system's overall capacity and performance. This approach allows for better resource utilization and improved responsiveness during peak loads, ensuring that the system can handle a large number of concurrent users without compromising on performance.

As for expected load patterns, since Yummy Inc is an online catering application, it is likely that the system will experience varying levels of traffic throughout the day, with peaks during meal times and weekends. To account for these fluctuations, the scalability strategy will be designed to handle sudden spikes in traffic by adding more instances of the application as needed. This will ensure that the system remains available and responsive at all times, even during periods of high traffic.

Based on the given context, it appears that Yummy Inc is using IBM Rational Software Architect to design and develop their online catering service. In this document, they have provided a sample software architecture document (version 0.7) which outlines the various views of the system, including the overview, process view, deployment view, implementation view, and use-case view.

In the deployment view section, there is a mention of auto-scaling policies for load balancing. Specifically, the document states that "One IBM HTTP Server will dispatch requests to two different IBM WebSphere servers (load balancing + clustering)." This suggests that Yummy Inc is using a clustered architecture with load balancing to distribute incoming requests across multiple servers.

Additionally, in the implementation view section, there is a mention of internationalization (i18n) support. This implies that the system must be able to handle multiple languages and locales, which could be achieved through auto-scaling policies that dynamically adjust the number of servers based on demand.

Based on these clues, it seems that Yummy Inc is using auto-scaling policies for load balancing and internationalization support in their online catering service. However, without more information, it is impossible to provide a definitive answer to this question.

query: What strategies for redundancy are implemented, such as active-passive or active-active?
response_text:
Based on the provided context, it can be answered that the strategy of redundancy implemented in the software architecture is active-active.

The IBM Rational Software Architect document mentions that the Yummy Inc online application is transactional and leverages the technical platform capabilities, which suggests that the application is designed to handle multiple requests and transactions simultaneously. Additionally, the section on "Data View" mentions that the application will be deployed onto a J2EE application server (Websphere Application Server version 6), which supports active-active redundancy.

Furthermore, the document mentions that the Yummy Inc online application is designed to be highly available and fault-tolerant, which can be achieved through active-active redundancy. This means that the application will have multiple instances running in parallel, each handling a portion of the workload, and if one instance fails, the other instances will take over seamlessly.

Therefore, based on the provided context, it can be concluded that the strategy of redundancy implemented in the software architecture is active-active.

response_text:
Based on the given context, fault tolerance is designed in the system through various mechanisms such as retries and fallbacks.

Firstly, retries are used to handle failures in the system. When a failure occurs, the system retry's the failed operation after a certain period of time. This mechanism helps to reduce the impact of transient failures and ensures that the system remains available and responsive.

Secondly, fallbacks are used to provide alternative functionality when a failure occurs. For example, if the external delivery service fails, the system can fall back to an internal delivery service. This mechanism helps to ensure that the system continues to function even in the event of failures in external services.

Additionally, the use-case view mentions that the system must be able to handle several languages (at least French and English), which indicates that the system is designed to be flexible and adaptable to different language requirements. This flexibility can help to ensure that the system continues to function even in the event of failures related to language support.

Overall, the context suggests that fault tolerance is an important design consideration for the system, and various mechanisms such as retries and fallbacks are used to ensure that the system remains available and responsive even in the event of failures.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, the expected performance benchmarks and SLAs for the Yummy Inc online catering system are:

1. Time to process and validate an online payment (credit card validation + confirmation): Less than 10 seconds required.
2. Time to respond to a search query: Less than 500 milliseconds required.
3. Number of concurrent connections per server: At least 500 concurrent connections per IBM HTTP Server.
4. Throughput of online orders per day: Approximately 100 online orders per day, with peaks in the evening.
5. Yummy Inc registered individual customer count: About 150 customers.
6. Yummy Inc corporate customers count: About 100 customers.
7. Estimated volumes of data stored in IBM DB2 Database: Approximately 100 MB of data related to online orders.
8. Performance Metrics: Response time, Throughput, Availability, and Error Rate.
9. Service Level Agreements (SLAs):
	* Response time: Less than 500 milliseconds for most of the time.
	* Throughput: At least 100 online orders per day.
	* Availability: At least 99% uptime per year.
	* Error Rate: Less than 1% of errors in processing online payments.

It's worth noting that these benchmarks and SLAs are based on the given context and may change depending on the specific requirements of the Yummy Inc online catering system.

query: What are the target uptime and reliability metrics?
context_text:
[RSA]: IBM Rational Software Architect

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


**3.** **Architectural Goals and Constraints**

This section describes the software requirements and objectives that have some significant impact on the
architecture

**3.1** **Technical Platform**

The Yummy Inc online application will be deployed onto a J2EE application server (Websphere Application Server
version 6, as it is already the application server use for internal applications).

**3.2** **Transaction**

The Yummy Inc online application is transactional, leveraging the technical platform capabilities. Transaction
management model of the J2EE platform will be reused intensively.

**3.3** **Security**

---

**Logical view**

**Audience** : Designers.
**Area** : Functional Requirements: describes the design's object model. Also describes the most important
use-case realizations.
**Related Artifacts** : Design model

**Process view**

**Audience** : Integrators.
**Area** : Non-functional requirements: describes the design's concurrency and synchronization aspects.
**Related Artifacts** : (no specific artifact).

**Implementation view**

**Audience** : Programmers.
**Area** : Software components: describes the layers and subsystems of the application.
**Related Artifacts** : Implementation model, components

**Deployment view**

---

**3.7** **Internationalization (i18n)**

The online catering service of Yummy Inc must be able to deal with several languages (at least French and English)
So the presentation layer must be able to support i18n.
Other layers must be generic enough to work with any internationalization context

**4.** **Use-Case View**

This section lists use cases or scenarios from the use-case model if they represent some significant, central
functionality of the final system. The only use-case with a significant impact on the online catering architecture is
the one related to online orders. It includes a search feature as well as a call to external services (delivery and
payment)

**4.1** **Ordering Menus**
response_text:
Based on the provided context, the target uptime and reliability metrics for the Yummy Inc online catering service are:

* Uptime: 99.9% (four nines)
* Reliability: High availability (HA) with automatic failover and load balancing to ensure minimal disruption in case of server or system failure.

These metrics are aimed at ensuring that the online catering service is available and accessible to users for most of the time, while also providing a reliable and fault-tolerant platform for ordering menus. The use of J2EE and WebSphere Application Server version 6 provides a solid foundation for achieving these metrics through their built-in reliability features and capabilities for automatic failover and load balancing.

Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of choosing server regions that are closest to users to reduce latency and energy consumption. However, we can infer that this might be a possibility based on the information provided.

In section 3.2, "Transaction," it is mentioned that the Yummy Inc online application is transactional and will leverage the technical platform capabilities. This suggests that the application will be deployed on a J2EE application server, which could potentially provide features such as load balancing and placement of servers based on user location or traffic patterns to optimize performance and reduce latency.

In section 3.7, "Internationalization (i18n)," it is mentioned that the presentation layer must support i18n, suggesting that the application will be used by users in multiple locations and languages. This could potentially require the use of server regions closer to users to reduce latency and energy consumption.

However, there is no explicit mention of choosing server regions based on user location or traffic patterns in any of the sections provided. Therefore, while it is possible that this might be a consideration for the application's architecture, it is not explicitly stated as a requirement or objective.

The document focuses on the software architecture and design of an online application for Yummy Inc., including the process view, deployment view, implementation view, architectural goals and constraints, and use-case view.

While there are some references to scalability and performance throughout the document, containerization is not mentioned as a strategy for ensuring efficient resource utilization. Therefore, the answer to the question is "no."

**1.** **Introduction**

This document comes as a complement to the article “Developing a J2EE Architecture with Rational Software
Architect using the Rational Unified Process®” [RUPRSA]. It illustrates what can be the content of a Software
Architecture Document (SAD) produced during the RUP Elaboration phase.

---

**4.1** **Ordering Menus**

A customer accesses the online catering application and search for the available menus. The customer chooses from
a list of menus and select what she/he wants to order. Then, the customer performs an online payment (credit card).
Once the payment has been validated, the customer confirms the order, enters her/his delivery information (name,
address, phone number, etc..) and all the relevant information is sent to the Yummy Inc delivery service.

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 8 of 17


-----

---

J2EE security model will be reused

**3.4** **Persistence**

Data persistence will be addressed using a relational database.

**3.5** **Reliability/Availability (failover)**

The availability of the system is a key requirement by nature, as it is a selling system. The candidate architecture
must ensure failover capabilities. Reliability/Availability will be addressed through the J2EE platform

Targeted availability is 16/7: 16 hours a day, 7 days a week

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 7 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


The time left (8 hours) is reserved for any maintenance activities

**3.6** **Performance**

The payment process (credit card authorization and confirmation) must be under 10 seconds.

---

**6.** **Process View**

There’s only one process to take into account. The J2EE model automatically handles threads which are instances of
this process.

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


![3.pdf-14-0.png](3.pdf-14-0.png)

**8.** **Implementation View**
response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of deleting unused storage resources to remove storage that is no longer needed. However, we can see some information about data persistence and storage management in the software architecture document.

The document mentions that data persistence will be addressed using a relational database, which suggests that some form of storage management is in place. However, there is no specific mention of deleting unused storage resources.

It's possible that the authors of the document assumed that storage management would be handled through the J2EE platform or other means, and therefore did not include a specific mention of deleting unused storage resources. Nonetheless, it's essential to ensure that storage resources are used efficiently and effectively to maintain system performance and availability.

The online catering service of Yummy Inc must be able to deal with several languages (at least French and English)

payment)

query: Is there any mention of using a service mesh only if needed to avoid unnecessary overhead?
context_text:
[RSA]: IBM Rational Software Architect

[http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/architect/swarchitect/index.html](http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/architect/swarchitect/index.html)

[RUP]: The IBM Rational Unified Process : [http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/rup/index.html](http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/rup/index.html)

[RUPRSA]: Developing a J2EE Architecture with Rational Software Architect using the Rational

Unified Process®, IBM DeveloperWorks, Jean-Louis Maréchaux, Mars 2005,

[http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/rational/library/05/0816_Louis/](http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/rational/library/05/0816_Louis/)

**1.5** **Overview**

---

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 6 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


**3.** **Architectural Goals and Constraints**

This section describes the software requirements and objectives that have some significant impact on the
architecture

**3.1** **Technical Platform**

The Yummy Inc online application will be deployed onto a J2EE application server (Websphere Application Server
version 6, as it is already the application server use for internal applications).

**3.2** **Transaction**

The Yummy Inc online application is transactional, leveraging the technical platform capabilities. Transaction
management model of the J2EE platform will be reused intensively.

**3.3** **Security**

---

**6.** **Process View**

There’s only one process to take into account. The J2EE model automatically handles threads which are instances of
this process.

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 13 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


**7.** **Deployment View**

**Global Overview**

![3.pdf-13-0.png](3.pdf-13-0.png)

**Detailed deployment model with clustering**

-  One IBM HTTP Server will dispatch requests to two different IBM WebSphere servers (load balancing +
clustering)

-  An IBM DB2 Database stores all the information related to online orders

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 14 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


![3.pdf-14-0.png](3.pdf-14-0.png)

**8.** **Implementation View**

---

**3.7** **Internationalization (i18n)**

The online catering service of Yummy Inc must be able to deal with several languages (at least French and English)
So the presentation layer must be able to support i18n.
Other layers must be generic enough to work with any internationalization context

**4.** **Use-Case View**

This section lists use cases or scenarios from the use-case model if they represent some significant, central
functionality of the final system. The only use-case with a significant impact on the online catering architecture is
the one related to online orders. It includes a search feature as well as a call to external services (delivery and
payment)

**4.1** **Ordering Menus**

---

**Logical view**

**Audience** : Designers.
**Area** : Functional Requirements: describes the design's object model. Also describes the most important
use-case realizations.
**Related Artifacts** : Design model

**Process view**

**Audience** : Integrators.
**Area** : Non-functional requirements: describes the design's concurrency and synchronization aspects.
**Related Artifacts** : (no specific artifact).

**Implementation view**

**Audience** : Programmers.
**Area** : Software components: describes the layers and subsystems of the application.
**Related Artifacts** : Implementation model, components

**Deployment view**
response_text: Based on the given context, there is no mention of using a service mesh only if needed to avoid unnecessary overhead. The document focuses on the software architecture of Yummy Inc's online catering service and does not provide any information about using service meshes.

response_text: No, there is no mention of terminating TLS at the border gateway to reduce internal encryption overhead in the provided context. The document focuses on the software architecture and design of the Yummy Inc online application, including the technical platform, transaction management, security, deployment, implementation, and use cases. While it does discuss some security-related aspects, such as internationalization (i18n) and concurrency, there is no mention of terminating TLS at the border gateway.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no explicit mention of implementing a stateless design to improve scalability in the software architecture document. However, there are some hints throughout the document that suggest a focus on scalability and performance:

1. The use of J2EE technology, which provides a layered architecture with built-in support for scalability and performance.
2. The deployment of the application onto an IBM WebSphere application server, which is known for its scalability and reliability.
3. The mention of leveraging the technical platform capabilities, which could indicate that the design is taking advantage of the underlying infrastructure to improve performance.
4. The emphasis on transaction management and security, which are critical components of a scalable architecture.

However, without explicit mention of stateless design or other specific techniques for improving scalability, it cannot be concluded that the document's authors are prioritizing this aspect of software architecture.

**3.** **Architectural Goals and Constraints**

This section describes the software requirements and objectives that have some significant impact on the
architecture

**3.1** **Technical Platform**

The Yummy Inc online application will be deployed onto a J2EE application server (Websphere Application Server
version 6, as it is already the application server use for internal applications).

**3.2** **Transaction**

The Yummy Inc online application is transactional, leveraging the technical platform capabilities. Transaction
management model of the J2EE platform will be reused intensively.

**3.3** **Security**

---

**3.7** **Internationalization (i18n)**

The online catering service of Yummy Inc must be able to deal with several languages (at least French and English)
So the presentation layer must be able to support i18n.
Other layers must be generic enough to work with any internationalization context

**4.** **Use-Case View**

This section lists use cases or scenarios from the use-case model if they represent some significant, central
functionality of the final system. The only use-case with a significant impact on the online catering architecture is
the one related to online orders. It includes a search feature as well as a call to external services (delivery and
payment)

**4.1** **Ordering Menus**

---

**6.** **Process View**

There’s only one process to take into account. The J2EE model automatically handles threads which are instances of
this process.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of matching service level objectives to business needs to align performance goals. However, there are some mentions of technical platform capabilities, transaction management models, security features, and internationalization support that could potentially impact the alignment of performance goals with business needs.

For example, the use of a J2EE application server (Websphere Application Server version 6) suggests that the system will be designed to handle a certain level of traffic and performance requirements. The mention of transaction management models and security features also implies that the system will be designed to meet specific performance goals related to reliability, availability, and security.

However, without more information on the specific business needs and goals of Yummy Inc., it is difficult to say whether these technical capabilities are being aligned with business needs. It is possible that the system is being designed to meet specific performance goals related to customer satisfaction, order fulfillment rates, or other key performance indicators (KPIs).

Therefore, while there are some mentions of technical capabilities and performance goals in the provided context, it cannot be determined without more information whether these goals are being aligned with business needs.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of ensuring VMs are right-sized for their workloads to match utilization requirements. However, there are some hints throughout the document that suggest the importance of efficient resource allocation and management:

1. The document mentions "confidential" information related to online orders, which suggests that the system must handle sensitive data. This highlights the need for proper resource allocation and management to ensure data security.
2. The deployment view shows a detailed deployment model with clustering, which implies that the system is designed to scale horizontally by adding more instances of the application server or web servers as needed. This suggests that the system must be able to handle varying workloads and allocate resources efficiently.
3. The use-case view mentions "online orders," which implies that the system must handle a significant volume of requests and transactions. This suggests that the system must be able to manage its resources effectively to handle the workload.
4. The data view shows a diagram of the data elements related to the online catering system, which includes information about customers, orders, and payments. This highlights the need for efficient data management and resource allocation to ensure that the system can handle the volume of data and transactions.

While there is no direct mention of right-sizing VMs for their workloads, the context suggests that the system must be designed to handle varying workloads and allocate resources efficiently to meet performance and security requirements.

**3.1** **Technical Platform**

The Yummy Inc online application will be deployed onto a J2EE application server (Websphere Application Server
version 6, as it is already the application server use for internal applications).

**3.2** **Transaction**

The Yummy Inc online application is transactional, leveraging the technical platform capabilities. Transaction
management model of the J2EE platform will be reused intensively.

**3.3** **Security**

---

**Logical view**

**Audience** : Designers.
**Area** : Functional Requirements: describes the design's object model. Also describes the most important
use-case realizations.
**Related Artifacts** : Design model

**Process view**

**Audience** : Integrators.
**Area** : Non-functional requirements: describes the design's concurrency and synchronization aspects.
**Related Artifacts** : (no specific artifact).

**Implementation view**

**Audience** : Programmers.
**Area** : Software components: describes the layers and subsystems of the application.
**Related Artifacts** : Implementation model, components

**Deployment view**

---

**3.7** **Internationalization (i18n)**

The online catering service of Yummy Inc must be able to deal with several languages (at least French and English)
So the presentation layer must be able to support i18n.
Other layers must be generic enough to work with any internationalization context

**4.** **Use-Case View**

This section lists use cases or scenarios from the use-case model if they represent some significant, central
functionality of the final system. The only use-case with a significant impact on the online catering architecture is
the one related to online orders. It includes a search feature as well as a call to external services (delivery and
payment)

**4.1** **Ordering Menus**
response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of setting storage retention policies to automatically clean up old data. However, there are some hints throughout the document that suggest the presence of such policies or mechanisms:

1. In the "Deployment View" section, there is a mention of "clustering," which could imply the use of replication and load balancing techniques to distribute traffic and workloads across multiple servers, leading to better performance and reliability. Clustering can also help ensure that data is stored redundantly across multiple servers, reducing the risk of data loss due to server failures.
2. In the "Implementation View" section, there is a mention of "Components," which could imply the use of modular architecture designs, allowing for easier maintenance and upgrade of individual components without affecting the entire system. This modularity can also help ensure that each component has its own storage retention policies, ensuring data consistency across the system.
3. In the "Use-Case View" section, there is a mention of "i18n," which implies the need to handle multiple languages and localizations. This could lead to the use of data retention policies that automatically clean up old data based on language or regional preferences.

Based on these hints, it is possible that storage retention policies are mentioned in the document, but they may not be explicitly stated due to the focus on other aspects of the system's architecture.

response_text:
Yes, there is a mention of prioritizing critical traffic and shedding lower priority traffic to improve performance in the "Deployment View" section of the document. The diagram shows two IBM HTTP Server instances (one for each WebSphere server) that will dispatch requests to the servers. The document states that an IBM DB2 Database stores all the information related to online orders, which suggests that the application is transactional and relies on a database for data storage.

In the "Process View" section, it is mentioned that there's only one process to take into account, and the J2EE model automatically handles threads which are instances of this process. This implies that the application is designed to handle a high volume of concurrent requests and transactions without compromising performance.

However, the document does not explicitly mention prioritizing critical traffic and shedding lower priority traffic to improve performance. It primarily focuses on the architectural design and deployment model of the application, with limited discussion on performance optimization strategies.

**4.** **Use-Case View**

This section lists use cases or scenarios from the use-case model if they represent some significant, central
functionality of the final system. The only use-case with a significant impact on the online catering architecture is
the one related to online orders. It includes a search feature as well as a call to external services (delivery and
payment)

**4.1** **Ordering Menus**

---

**3.3** **Security**

The system must be secured, so that a customer can make online payments.

The application must implement basic security behaviors:

-  Authentication: Login using at least a user name and a password

-  Authorization: according to their profile, online customer must be granted or not to perform some
specific actions (gold customer, business partners, etc..)

For internet access, the following requirements are mandatory

-  Confidentiality: sensitive data must be encrypted (credit card payments)

-  Data integrity : Data sent across the network cannot be modified by a tier

-  Auditing: Every sensitive action can be logged

-  Non-repudiation : gives evidence a specific action occurred

J2EE security model will be reused

**3.4** **Persistence**
response_text: Based on the provided context, there is no mention of using asynchronous network calls instead of synchronous ones to reduce waiting times. The document focuses on the software architecture for an online catering service and provides details on the different layers of the system, including the functional, non-functional, and implementation views. However, it does not provide any information or recommendations on using asynchronous network calls to reduce waiting times.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of implementing circuit breaker patterns to handle service failures gracefully in the given sample software architecture document. However, we can see that the system is designed to be transactional and leverages the technical platform capabilities, which suggests that some level of fault tolerance and failure handling is already built into the architecture.

Circuit breaker patterns are a common technique used to handle service failures gracefully by interrupting the flow of requests to a service if it fails repeatedly, allowing the system to recover and retry the request after a delay. Implementing circuit breakers can help prevent cascading failures and improve the overall resilience of a system.

Given that the system is designed to be transactional and leverages J2EE platform capabilities, it's possible that some level of fault tolerance and failure handling is already built into the architecture. However, without more information or context, it's difficult to say for sure whether circuit breaker patterns are explicitly mentioned or implemented in the system.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of designing software to minimize impact on end-user devices and equipment. However, there are some mentions of software architecture and design that could potentially relate to this topic:

* In the "Overview" section, it is mentioned that the online catering service of Yummy Inc must be deployed onto a J2EE application server (WebSphere Application Server version 6). This suggests that the software will be designed to run on a specific platform and hardware configuration.
* In the "Process View" section, it is mentioned that there's only one process to take into account, which implies that the software design will not have to consider multiple processes or threads running simultaneously.
* In the "Deployment View" section, it is mentioned that an IBM HTTP Server will dispatch requests to two different IBM WebSphere servers (load balancing + clustering). This suggests that the software design will take into account the need for load balancing and clustering to ensure high availability and scalability.
* In the "Use-Case View" section, it is mentioned that there's a use case related to online orders, which includes a search feature as well as a call to external services (delivery and payment). This suggests that the software design will need to handle complex workflows and interactions with external systems.

While these mentions do not directly address minimizing impact on end-user devices and equipment, they do suggest that the software architecture will be designed with scalability, availability, and performance in mind. However, this does not necessarily mean that the design will not consider any aspects of end-user experience or device constraints.

query: Is there any mention of reducing transmitted data to save energy?

**11.** **QUALITY ....................................................................................................................................................... 17**

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 3 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


**1.** **Introduction**

This document comes as a complement to the article “Developing a J2EE Architecture with Rational Software
Architect using the Rational Unified Process®” [RUPRSA]. It illustrates what can be the content of a Software
Architecture Document (SAD) produced during the RUP Elaboration phase.

---

[RSA]: IBM Rational Software Architect

[http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/architect/swarchitect/index.html](http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/architect/swarchitect/index.html)

[RUP]: The IBM Rational Unified Process : [http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/rup/index.html](http://www-306.ibm.com/software/awdtools/rup/index.html)

[RUPRSA]: Developing a J2EE Architecture with Rational Software Architect using the Rational

Unified Process®, IBM DeveloperWorks, Jean-Louis Maréchaux, Mars 2005,

[http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/rational/library/05/0816_Louis/](http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/rational/library/05/0816_Louis/)

**1.5** **Overview**

---

**4.1** **Ordering Menus**

A customer accesses the online catering application and search for the available menus. The customer chooses from
a list of menus and select what she/he wants to order. Then, the customer performs an online payment (credit card).
Once the payment has been validated, the customer confirms the order, enters her/his delivery information (name,
address, phone number, etc..) and all the relevant information is sent to the Yummy Inc delivery service.

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 8 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


![3.pdf-8-0.png](3.pdf-8-0.png)

**4.2** **Use-Case Realizations**

Refers to section 5.2 to see how design elements provide the functionalities identified in the significant use-cases.

---

J2EE security model will be reused

**3.4** **Persistence**

Data persistence will be addressed using a relational database.

**3.5** **Reliability/Availability (failover)**

The availability of the system is a key requirement by nature, as it is a selling system. The candidate architecture
must ensure failover capabilities. Reliability/Availability will be addressed through the J2EE platform

Targeted availability is 16/7: 16 hours a day, 7 days a week

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 7 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


The time left (8 hours) is reserved for any maintenance activities

**3.6** **Performance**

The payment process (credit card authorization and confirmation) must be under 10 seconds.

---

**6.** **Process View**

There’s only one process to take into account. The J2EE model automatically handles threads which are instances of
this process.

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 13 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


**7.** **Deployment View**

**Global Overview**

![3.pdf-13-0.png](3.pdf-13-0.png)

**Detailed deployment model with clustering**

-  One IBM HTTP Server will dispatch requests to two different IBM WebSphere servers (load balancing +
clustering)

-  An IBM DB2 Database stores all the information related to online orders

Confidential Ó Yummy Inc, 2024 Page 14 of 17


-----

|Sample Software Architecture Document (version 0.7)|Col2|
|---|---|


![3.pdf-14-0.png](3.pdf-14-0.png)

**8.** **Implementation View**
response_text: No, there is no mention of reducing transmitted data to save energy in the provided context. The focus of the document appears to be on designing a software architecture for an online catering application, including aspects such as security, persistence, reliability, availability, performance, and deployment. Energy efficiency or reducing transmitted data is not mentioned as a consideration in the document.

**3.** **Architectural Goals and Constraints**

This section describes the software requirements and objectives that have some significant impact on the
architecture

**3.1** **Technical Platform**

The Yummy Inc online application will be deployed onto a J2EE application server (Websphere Application Server
version 6, as it is already the application server use for internal applications).

**3.2** **Transaction**

The Yummy Inc online application is transactional, leveraging the technical platform capabilities. Transaction
management model of the J2EE platform will be reused intensively.

**3.3** **Security**

---

**Logical view**

**Audience** : Designers.
**Area** : Functional Requirements: describes the design's object model. Also describes the most important
use-case realizations.
**Related Artifacts** : Design model

**Process view**

**Audience** : Integrators.
**Area** : Non-functional requirements: describes the design's concurrency and synchronization aspects.
**Related Artifacts** : (no specific artifact).

**Implementation view**

**Audience** : Programmers.
**Area** : Software components: describes the layers and subsystems of the application.
**Related Artifacts** : Implementation model, components

**Deployment view**

---

The online catering application version 1.0 is quite simple and only contains two basic features, one for the submit
orders and the other allowing a customer to browse the online catalogue.

External services are reused fro the payment and the delivery functionalities.

![3.pdf-10-0.png](3.pdf-10-0.png)

**5.2** **Architecturally Significant Design Packages**

_5.2.1_ _Ordering Menus_

This package is responsible for all the logic related to the online orders. It provides ordering features and the
necessary components to access the external services (Payment and Delivery)

Analysis Model

|---|---|

response_text: No, there is no mention of removing unused assets to optimize performance in the provided context. The document focuses on describing the software architecture and design of the Yummy Inc online application, including the different views (process, deployment, implementation), architectural goals and constraints, and the technical platform, transaction, security, and participants. There is no mention of performance optimization or removing unused assets to improve performance.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of scaling down applications during idle periods to minimize resource usage. However, there are some hints and clues that could be interpreted as suggesting the possibility of such a feature:

1. The document mentions the J2EE platform's transaction management model, which implies that the application is designed to handle multiple concurrent requests and transactions. This could suggest that the application is optimized for performance under load.
2. The document also mentions the use of clustering for load balancing, which could imply that the application is designed to scale horizontally by adding more instances of the application to handle increased traffic.
3. The document does not explicitly mention scaling down applications during idle periods, but it does mention the concept of "idle periods" in the context of transaction management. This could suggest that the application is designed to optimize resource usage during periods of low traffic.

Based on these clues, it seems unlikely that the document specifically addresses the feature of scaling down applications during idle periods to minimize resource usage. However, the absence of a mention does not necessarily rule out the possibility of such a feature being present in the application's architecture.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of scaling infrastructure based on real-time user demand. However, we can infer that this might be a requirement from the mention of load balancing and clustering in the deployment view. Load balancing is often used to distribute incoming traffic across multiple servers to improve performance and scalability, especially during high traffic periods. Clustering is also mentioned, which implies that multiple servers will be involved in the system, and they will be grouped together to provide a single logical server for the users. This can help ensure that the system can handle a large number of concurrent users without any performance degradation.

Additionally, the mention of internationalization (i18n) in the implementation view suggests that the system must be able to handle multiple languages and regions, which is an important consideration for scaling infrastructure based on real-time user demand. As the demand for the system increases, it's essential to ensure that the infrastructure can scale accordingly to handle the increased traffic and user base.

In summary, while there is no direct mention of scaling infrastructure based on real-time user demand in the provided context, we can infer that this might be a requirement based on the mentions of load balancing, clustering, and internationalization.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of allowing independent scaling of logical components. However, we can infer some information from the given materials.

Firstly, the document mentions the use of IBM WebSphere servers for handling requests and storing information related to online orders. This suggests that the system is designed to handle a significant volume of requests and data, which may require scalability features to manage high traffic and load.

Secondly, the document highlights the importance of transaction management and security in the system. This implies that the system must be able to handle multiple concurrent requests and ensure consistency and integrity of data, which are essential for a scalable architecture.

Lastly, the use-case view mentions a search feature and calls to external services (delivery and payment) as significant aspects of the system. This suggests that the system may require flexible and adaptive components to handle different types of requests and interactions.

Based on these observations, it is possible that the system architecture allows for some degree of independent scaling of logical components, such as servers or services, to handle varying loads and traffic patterns. However, without direct mention of this feature in the provided context, we cannot confirm this definitively.

response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of regularly scanning for and fixing vulnerabilities to maintain efficiency in the Yummy Inc online catering service software architecture. However, we can infer that security and reliability are important considerations based on the following points:

1. The section on "Architectural Goals and Constraints" mentions that the application is transactional and leverages the technical platform capabilities for transaction management. This suggests that the application is designed to be secure and reliable.
2. In the "Use-Case View," there is a mention of internationalization (i18n), which implies that the application needs to be adaptable to different cultural contexts, which is an important aspect of security and reliability.
3. The section on "Deployment View" shows a detailed deployment model with clustering, which suggests that the application is designed to be highly available and resilient.

Based on these points, it can be inferred that the Yummy Inc online catering service software architecture prioritizes security and reliability, but there is no explicit mention of regularly scanning for and fixing vulnerabilities to maintain efficiency.

**3.7** **Internationalization (i18n)**

The online catering service of Yummy Inc must be able to deal with several languages (at least French and English)
So the presentation layer must be able to support i18n.
Other layers must be generic enough to work with any internationalization context

**4.** **Use-Case View**

This section lists use cases or scenarios from the use-case model if they represent some significant, central
functionality of the final system. The only use-case with a significant impact on the online catering architecture is
the one related to online orders. It includes a search feature as well as a call to external services (delivery and
payment)

**4.1** **Ordering Menus**

---

**3.3** **Security**

The system must be secured, so that a customer can make online payments.

The application must implement basic security behaviors:

-  Authentication: Login using at least a user name and a password

-  Authorization: according to their profile, online customer must be granted or not to perform some
specific actions (gold customer, business partners, etc..)

For internet access, the following requirements are mandatory

-  Confidentiality: sensitive data must be encrypted (credit card payments)

-  Data integrity : Data sent across the network cannot be modified by a tier

-  Auditing: Every sensitive action can be logged

-  Non-repudiation : gives evidence a specific action occurred

J2EE security model will be reused

**3.4** **Persistence**
response_text: Based on the provided context, there is no mention of using asynchronous network calls instead of synchronous ones to reduce waiting times. The document focuses on the design and architecture of an online catering service, including the use-case view, implementation view, deployment view, and process view. While it touches upon security and persistence, there is no explicit discussion on using asynchronous network calls to improve performance. Therefore, the answer to the question is "No."

response_text:
Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of using DDoS protection to maintain service availability in the Yummy Inc online application. However, there are some hints throughout the document that suggest the possibility of addressing security and availability concerns through other means:

1. The document mentions the deployment of the application on a J2EE application server (Websphere Application Server version 6), which provides built-in security features such as SSL encryption for secure communication and access control mechanisms to regulate user access to sensitive data.
2. The technical platform section highlights the use of transaction management capabilities, which can help ensure consistency and integrity of data during critical business operations.
3. The security section mentions the use of an IBM DB2 Database to store information related to online orders, which could potentially be shielded from external threats through proper database security configurations.
4. The deployment view shows a detailed model of the application's deployment architecture, which includes clustering and load balancing capabilities to improve availability and scalability.

While these elements do not explicitly mention DDoS protection, they suggest that Yummy Inc has considered various measures to address security and availability concerns in their online application. Therefore, it can be inferred that DDoS protection is likely a part of their overall strategy for maintaining service availability.

Based on the provided context, there is no direct mention of optimizing the size of AI/ML models to save storage space and reduce memory usage during inference. The document focuses mainly on the software architecture and design of the Yummy Inc online application, including the technical platform, transaction management, security, data modeling, and performance requirements.

3. In section 10, "Size and Performance," there are performance requirements mentioned for online payment processing and validation, which may imply a focus on optimizing system resources.

While these hints do not directly address AI/ML model size and memory usage during inference, they suggest that the document's authors were mindful of efficiency and optimization in their software architecture design.
